title: House hunters enjoy record low interest rates in competitive mortgage market
text:

Wed, Sep 9, 2015, 04:55 BST - UK Markets open in 3 hrs 5 mins House hunters enjoy record low interest rates in competitive mortgage market By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 13 hours ago 0.0028 0.0000 
Markets might be preparing for the Bank of England to hike interest rates, but high-street rates have hit a new low 
Home buyers are enjoying record low interest rates, as banks continue to cut borrowing costs in a competitive lending market. 
The average loan in the three months to the end of June came with an interest rate of 2.83pc, down from 2.99pc in the previous three-month period. 
That is the lowest rate since the Bank of England and the Financial Conduct Authority began gathering data on the market in 2007. 
• Mapped: House prices by London's Tube stops - £1m homes now reach zone 6 
Economists expect the Bank of England to raise interest rates in the next 12 months , but this does not appear to be feeding through to the rates paid by borrowers in any significant way. 
Nonetheless, buyers are increasingly keen to fix the rate on their loan for a period of several years. 
Officials said 78.9pc of loans given during the period were at fixed rates, up from 77.6pc in the first quarter. 
One factor driving down high-street interest rates is competition from challenger banks - smaller players who offer more choice to those mortgage borrowers willing to shop around for their loan. 
“We expect competitive pressures in UK retail banking to grow,” said credit ratings agency Standard (Other OTC: SNDH - news ) and Poor’s in a report on challenger banks. 
“Over the past 12 months they've become noteworthy in the mortgage market, a trend we think will continue.” 
Overall lending hit £52.5bn in the second quarter, up 15.1pc on the first quarter and up 1.9pc on the second quarter of 2014. 
• Jobs crisis looming as entry-level workers driven out of London by soaring rents 
However, the increase is not driven by owner-occupiers buying homes. The amount loaned to first-time buyers slid by 5pc on the year to £10.8bn. 
Instead, lending to buy-to-let investors increased by 18.6pc to £8.3bn, while remortgaging levels also increased by 10.5pc to £13.7bn, as homeowners rush to take advantage of cheap loans before interest rates go up.
